title: 114_hr2306
content: The Act is titled the "Obamacare Marriage Penalty Elimination Act" and aims to eliminate the marriage penalty in health insurance premium tax credit. The "Obamacare Marriage Penalty Elimination Act" aims to eliminate the marriage penalty in health insurance premium tax credit by allowing each spouse to have a separate credit based on their income. The text discusses how income splitting should not make either spouse ineligible for the health insurance premium tax credit if one spouse's income exceeds the poverty line for that spouse, while the other spouse's income exceeds the combined poverty line for both spouses. The text explains that dependents of the taxpayer can be allocated between spouses at the taxpayer's choice for determining family size and household income. The household income of each spouse and their dependents are considered for tax purposes. The number of dependents allocated to one spouse cannot exceed the other spouse by more than 1. Premiums determined separately for each spouse or dependent are taken into account accordingly. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after the enactment date. Premiums can be allocated between spouses as per the taxpayer's choice. The amendment reduces the poverty line eligibility limitation for health insurance premium tax credit. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 reduces the poverty line eligibility limitation for health insurance premium tax credit by changing the applicable percentage determined by the Secretary. The Obamacare Marriage Penalty Elimination Act reduces Federal revenues and increases Federal outlays. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, changing the applicable percentage for health insurance premium tax credit eligibility. Effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2015. Amendments to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act change the applicable percentage for health insurance premium tax credit eligibility. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2015.
